segments.text: Are you recording this time?
Were journalists' methods changed during the 60s?
Well, I don't think the basic methods changed any.
I can't recall that there were any revolutionary kinds of changes.
I think that...
They may have changed to the extent that there came to be less of a reliance on official sources for things.
I think the kind of tension that grew up between journalists and public officials, especially the police and prosecutors and like that, probably
probably led them to deal with other kinds of sources more.
And I guess if that's a change in method, then yeah, you could say that the method changed.
But beyond that, I can't think of anything that was essentially a change.
There were, of course, parts of journalism that developed during that time, the so-called underground press and the
and the so-called new journalism sort of thing that relied more on impressions and opinions and representations of situations rather than attempts to factually report situations, that kind of thing.
But that was outside mainstream journalism.
I don't think mainstream journalism changed much, except perhaps in a relationship of journalists to their sources.
But there certainly was a development of these other forms of journalism.
They really weren't new, of course.
We've had that kind of thing from time to time throughout our history.
But they certainly enjoyed a period of development at that time.
And some of the elements in that journalism have since spilled over into journalism today in terms of probably more of an emphasis on explanation and interpretation.
That's kind of an evolutionary change, I think.
I guess, yes, there was change, and no, there wasn't.
How prevalent were underground newspapers in Austin?
Well, there was one that was very prevalent.
It was called The Rag, which was published out around in the University of Texas neighborhood.
And in the beginning, of course, The Rag was typical of that kind of thing, in which it went out of its way to try to shock the establishment there.
Their vocabularies were pretty rich with four-letter words and they extolled the virtues of sex and drugs and nudity and anything that they calculated was going to infuriate the establishment.
That was their style.
As underground newspapers matured, they got away from that kind of
deliberately outrageous shock value kind of thing and began to deal more with issues and it really became respectable.
I guess the most clear example of that is the Los Angeles Free Press which began much in the way that I said and grew and
remains an alternative kind of a newspaper, but one that certainly is not that far from the mainstream and has become very successful.
I don't recall, around Austin, I don't recall that there was any other than the RAG, but the RAG was very widely distributed and widely read and certainly was a prominent feature of the
of the University of Texas area at that time.
You were mentioning less reliance on sources.
What about journalistic ethics?
Were they affected during this era?
Well, I guess maybe they were in some degree because

I think there was more of a willingness to use unnamed sources to protect sources because I think the feeling was that in order to get to the inside of some of these dissident movements that you had to deal with people on their terms.
I think that as time passed that
I guess we're getting really a little bit beyond this period.
But the Pentagon Papers business, for example, was a willingness on the part of highly responsible newspapers to use stolen information.
And so I think that presented an ethical problem, and it's one that journalism is still wrestling with.
I think what happened was that as journalists became

less and less willing to trust established sources, that is the officials, elected officials, police officials, that sort of thing, that they dropped into a kind of a situational ethic in which in order to get information that they were willing to justify means according to the ends that were being served.
And so I think
I think probably there came to be a higher reliance on situational ethics maybe during that period than there had been before.
And that generated what is a continuing debate about that very kind of thing, about the use of anonymous sources, about the use of stolen information, about reporters
operating undercover sting reporters, you know, journalistic sting operations, things like that.
Those are still hot topics in journalism, and I think they were really generated beginning with this period we're talking about.
How much did public and government distrust of media grow in this area?
public and government distrust of the media.
I think it did grow.
And the reason I think that it grew is because the media were dealing with lots of subjects that the public really didn't want to acknowledge.
I think public

did not want to come to grips with the fact that the dissidents the hippies or whatever the term were that were being used for these people might have a point that they were human beings who were indulging in a different lifestyle all right i think that there was a feeling among a lot of people that the media were in effect promoting these
disident causes, I think they sometimes felt that the media were promoting the use of marijuana and other drugs.

I think that a feeling grew that because the media were covering these topics, that that automatically meant that the media favored these kinds of people and these kinds of lifestyles and that the media
therefore were anti-establishment.
Now, the truth of the matter is that if you read the editorial columns of that time, you're going to find that the mass media were about as conservative as ever.
But in the news columns, I think quite a different kind of an impression might be gained.
And especially as the media began to be critical of the Vietnam War, as the war grew on and there got to be a realization that
that information was being jiggled around pretty significantly by the government and lots of lies were being told.
And so I think that public and officialdom began to distrust the media sort of lumping
the messenger in with the people where the messages came from that they didn't like.
So yeah, I think distrust did grow during that period.
I think the public doesn't distinguish a lot between editorial policies on the editorial page and news coverage.
And I'm not sure that they distinguish very clearly
Maybe they don't really differentiate as much as they should the difference between, say, the Los Angeles Free Press and the Los Angeles Times.
They just sort of lump them all in there.

And then television exacerbated that quite a bit, I think, because television, especially for the first time, very first time in our history, began to see pictures of a war that were unflattering to Americans.
Always in the past,
We had covered wars in a way that were unflattering to the other guy, but they didn't show that anything that was unflattering.
Our people were always heroes, their people were always fiends.
Well, in Vietnam, it didn't come out that way.
It turned out maybe everybody was a fiend.
It was a very confusing kind of war.
And we had the things like the My Lai Massacre and all that kind of stuff.
And so people had a high level of dissonance about all that.
They didn't want to deal with it.
It seemed that the media were going out of their way to portray a negative image of the United States and the United States Armed Forces and the United States purposes in Vietnam.
And so I think that really, probably even more in print, increased the distrust of the public in officialdom.
And that was during that time, of course, that people like Spiro Agnew

were making speeches in which they were talking about the eastern liberal establishment and about how Walter Cronkite could raise an eyebrow and control the opinions of the nation and all that kind of thing.
Television especially became a very easy scapegoat for the people who were trying to explain away all the social unrest and all the dissatisfaction with the Vietnam War and all that sort of thing.
So, yep, the distrust certainly increased.
Looking back, how extensive were the changes on the media?
And did they affect the small town papers, medium papers, and the large papers equally, or in what proportion?
Well, I think the things that have really affected the way mass media operate have been the recent technological changes.
And those really were not in effect at that time.
although some of the smaller papers already were beginning to switch to offset printing and that sort of thing.
So there's a change in that regard.
But I can't say beyond the kinds of things I've already talked about in terms of the relationship between the media and their sources and their audiences.
I can't think of any
special changes in operations or in techniques or anything like that that were especially different.
Maybe my mind is only blank, but I really can't.
It seems to me that significant changes have come about since that time in terms of development of cable television and satellite transmissions and television super stations in terms of
really rapid development of printing techniques and electronic newsroom technologies and things like that.
That's all happened since the period we're talking about.
Well, thank you very much.
You're welcome.
